snippet: Foreign policy luminaries who served in the two Bush administrations largely derided Donald J. Trump, and it was mutual. But some of the establishment figures’ opposition is softening....
abstract: Republican Party's foreign policy experts appear to have softened their  opposition to idea of Donald Trump presidency, despite fact they constituted fiercest anti-Trump contingent of party's establishment during election; it is open question whether Trump will accept their help or advice, as he is known to hold grudges and has boasted he knows better than experts about foreign policy.

byline.original: By MARK MAZZETTI, HELENE COOPER and ERIC SCHMITT
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Michael S. Schmidt, Mark Landler, Maggie Haberman and Matthew Rosenberg.

lead_paragraph: Foreign policy luminaries who served in the two Bush administrations largely derided Donald J. Trump, and it was mutual. But some of the establishment figures’ opposition is softening.

headline.main: ‘Never Trump’ Becomes ‘Maybe Trump’ in Foreign Policy Sphere
headline.print_headline: ‘Never Trump’ Becomes ‘Maybe Trump’ in Foreign Policy Sphere
